RUBBER INDUSTRY (ANTI-INFLATIONARY CESS) FUND BOARD,
FEDERATION OF MALAYA
(Addition to First Schedule of Income Tax Ordinance)


10.16 a.m.

    The Financial Secretary (Mr T. M. Hart): Sir, I beg to move,

    That this Assembly, pursuant to subsection (1) of section 106 of the Income Tax Ordinance (Chapter 166), resolves that the Rubber Industry (Anti-Inflationary Cess) Fund Board,

Column: 2596

Federation of Malaya, be added to the First Schedule to the said Ordinance.

    This application has been received from the Rubber Industry (Anti-Inflationary Cess) Fund Board under section 13 (1) (e) of the Income Tax Ordinance. Exemption is effected by the inclusion of the name of this public body in the First Schedule to the Ordinance. The objects of the Rubber Industry (Anti-Inflationary Cess) Fund Board are, inter alia, to divide the monies of the Fund which are derived from cesses charged from rubber exported from the Federation of Malaya between the owners of estates of 100 acres and over and small-holders. The monies of the Fund are to be disbursed when the gazetted price of rubber is less than $1 per lb, for three successive weeks. The monies in the case of estates are to be paid over in four equal quarterly instalments and in respect of smallholders the monies are to be paid into Fund B established under the Rubber Industry's Replanting Fund Ordinance, 1952, Federation of Malaya. All expenses incurred in administering the Fund are chargeable to the general revenues of the Federation. The High Commissioner in Council has power under the Ordinance to make a scheme to be administered by the Board for the disposal of the monies in the Fund when he may revoke or vary any existing scheme. The Board has to prepare annually an estimate of costs, charges and expenses likely to be incurred in administering the Fund during each year commencing the 1st of January. The Malayan Board of Income Tax has considered this case and considers that the Rubber Industry (Anti-Inflationary Cess) Fund Board may properly be included in the First Schedule to the Ordinance with effect from the 1st of January, 1957 and Government accepts the recommendation of the Board.

    Sir, I beg to move.

ALLEGED INACCURACIES CONTAINED IN SESSIONAL
PAPER NO. CMD. 33 OF 1957


10.19 a.m.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to move the motion which stands in my name. It reads,

    That this House deplores the inaccuracies contained in Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 33 of 1957 published by the Government on the 23rd August, 1957, in justification of the recent purge.

    We can understand the colonial power wishing to destroy the P.A.P. It makes no difference to them at this stage of the fight for freedom whether the P.A.P is Communist or non-Communist. We are uncompromisingly anti-colonial and we expect the colonial power to be uncompromisingly anti-P.A.P. But we cannot understand the Labour Front Coalition joining the colonial power in seeking to destroy the P.A.P. It is true we have little time or respect for many of the political rogues in the Labour Front but, surely there must be some social democrats in the Labour Front who should be able to see that it is against the interest of democratic socialism to attempt to destroy the P.A.P.

    For a closing down of the P.A.P is what the White Paper has attempted to prepare the way for-a White Paper presented and published by the Labour Front Government in conjunction with the colonial power.

    The attempt, Sir, was made in two ways : - First: by the deliberate suppression of certain facts so as to make it appear that the purge was intended to save the P.A.P. from capture by a Communist group - suppressio veri, suggestio falsi. It suppressed the truth that the leaders of this group the Government have arrested were on the point of capturing the Trades Union Congress by the 22nd of August and so by inference suggested the falsehood that the purge was because the P.A.P. had

Column: 2598

been captured by the Communists. Second: by falsely making it appear in the White Paper that the P.A.P. is a Communist front organisation when the Chief Minister knew as he admitted in his Press conference, reported in the Press of the 25th of August, that it is a genuine political organisation.

    The Chief Minister exploited the temporary difficulties of the P.A.P. We the P.A.P. have no Special Branch. Whether a person is a Communist or a Communist agent, only he knows and God knows. Between his conscience and God of course lies the Special Branch and it is up to them to show that these men whom they have arrested are Communists or Communist agents. We know some of these men as a dissident faction in the P.A.P. who tried to oppose and reverse the policy of the last Central Executive Committee of the P.A.P.

    But while we were engaged in a fight with this dissident faction, the Government waded in and arrested them and at the same time published a White Paper which made it appear that the Party was thereby saved from penetration and capture by the Communists. And so the Government tried to discredit us. But what are the facts which this White Paper does not disclose? With regard to the trade union position, the White Paper ended on page 6 with a statement in the middle of the page saying:

    "On July 18th a meeting of representatives of the S.T.U.W.C. [Singapore Trade Unions Working Committee was held at Middle Road at which tactics for strengthening its organisation and for gaining control of the T.U.C. were discussed."

    And there the story ends. We are led to believe that that was the position when the purge began. Can the Government deny that the leaders of this group they have arrested were on the point of capturing the T.U.C. by the evening of the 22nd August when the purge began? Why did the White Paper not disclose that for some time since the return of the Chief Minister's driver Mr Lee Yew Seng (who looks after the T.U.C. for him) returned from his May Day visit to Peking, where a photograph was taken of him and the

Column: 2599

Chinese Prime Minister Mr Chou En-lai, this group had been making progress with him, that things had reached the point where on the night of the 22nd the so-called 32 unions led by this group were about to be accepted into the T.U.C. and so capture it, leaving the Labour Front without their 'mass' base? Why was it not disclosed that on the night of the 22nd itself when the Police surrounded the premises at Middle Road the so-called 32 unions special committee was holding a meeting to finalise arrangements for their joining in and capturing of the T.U.C.?

    Is it not because it would have been acutely embarrassing for the Labour Front to confess that it acted to save the T.U.C.? And can the Government deny that it was this same group that fought the Labour Front candidate in the Cairnhill by-elections where they organised support for one Mr Goh Kong Beng and so split the working class vote and defeated the Labour Front candidate? Why was this episode not disclosed? Had this no bearing on what followed?

    There were no civil disturbances on the 22nd of August, no obvious cause for a purge. So the conflict in the P.A.P. was exploited. The Chief Minister thought he could hurt both groups in the P.A.P.: arresting one because he suspected it to be Communist, and by the timing making it appear that the other had precipitated the arrest. To achieve this, the White Paper preoccupied itself with the P.A.P. and the real reason that the T.U.C. was then in imminent danger was concealed. Sir, it is clear that the White Paper must have been prepared quite some time ago for it to have been published on the 23rd of August, the day after the purge. But why, it may be asked, was the purge not made earlier, at the height of the conflict in the P.A.P., so as to embarrass us even more? Was it not because there was an Assembly sitting fixed for the 21st of August and the Government disliked the prospect of an early debate and so waited till the 22nd, the following day?

Column: 2600



    We know that the Government's action was calculated to embarrass us. This purge and the White Paper were in the making quite some time before the P.A.P. annual conference fixed for the 4th of August. If the Government was as well informed as the White Paper suggests, then they must have been forewarned that a conflict was likely on the 4th of August. The Government waited for this to happen, waited until the T.U.C. was threatened, waited until the Assembly sitting of the 21st was over and then moved in. On the 22nd of August 1957, V.I.P.'s from all over the world were arriving for the Merdeka celebrations in Kuala Lumpur - a most inopportune moment for a purge, for if the mass arrests contemplated had provoked resistance and riots, it would have been most embarrassing for the Government. Yet the Government had to move. I suggest the conclusion is therefore irresistible that the Government had to accept this risk because of a compelling reason - the rescue of the T.U.C., the Government's 'mass' base, from imminent danger. It is therefore dishonest of the Government to have suppressed this vital fact.

    But the second way of trying to destroy the P.A.P. was even more dishonest. If the Chief Minister knew that the P.A.P. was a genuine political Party, then why did he not say so in the White Paper instead of making it appear that the P.A.P. is not a genuine political Party but a Communist front organisation? Why say in paragraphs 36 and 37 that the Communists had dominated the Party and would do so for good? Perhaps the Chief Minister has not read paragraphs 36 and 37. Paragraph 36 reads:

    "New leaders and organisers have taken the place of those removed. As each month goes by, Communist activities become more frequent and more blatant; and the power of persons known to be Communist grows. Once again the aim is to bring about a united front of workers, farmers and students supported by a favourable press and by political sympathisers. The gravest developments have been amongst the workers. A determined and successful bid for controlling the P.A.P. has been the second feature of recent months. Here the Communists have worked

Column: 2601

through the cultural, educational and propaganda groups in the P.A.P. and through them have gone far to obtain domination of the whole Party organisation. There has also been revived activity amongst students, farmers, women and "cultural" groups."

    Paragraph 37 reads:

    "It is evident that once again a serious threat is developing. Communists and their agents are back in key positions daily increasing their propaganda and their power, and steadily strengthening the extent of their control and thus again building up a united Communist front. If the situation is allowed to deteriorate, it will become increasingly difficult to check the threat, and decisive action will be resisted with consequent rioting and blood-shed. From past experience it is quite clear that there is no prospect at all that these legal organisations will be able to purge themselves of Communist influence and conform to democratic and constitutional practice."

    Why say in paragraphs 36 and 37 that we the P.A.P. have been dominated by the Communists and they would do so for good? Can it be that this White Paper was not the work of the Chief Minister but of someone else who had got it past the Chief Minister and his elected colleagues.

    If the Government was as well informed as it claims to be, it must have known that the P.A.P.'s activities were perfectly legitimate and commendable. We do not pretend that our Party is impervious to Communist penetration. No party is. The M.C.P. is denied political existence and must resort to clandestine methods to enter the constitutional political arena. Does the Labour Front deny that its organising secretary, a confessed ex-member of the Malayan Communist Party, closed down several Labour Front branches because he thought some Communists had gone in? Surely, the Government knew that some of the blatant and crude tactics in disseminating propaganda in the P.A.P. of a kind foreign to our Party's aims and objectives was the work of a few individuals, that the general membership were not parties to this, that the Party leadership was opposed to this, that they had consistently stamped out such activities and that they had been consistently firm and resolute in their non-Communist stand.

Column: 2602



    But the White Paper tried to make it appear that the Party leadership was weak, effete and ineffective and unable to resist penetration and so the Government had to step in. It says in paragraph 37 and I quote it again:

    "From past experience it is quite clear that there is no prospect at all that these legal organisations will be able to purge themselves of Communist influence and conform to democratic and constitutional practice."

    Let me tell the Government this, that we in the P.A.P. are quite capable of looking after ourselves and the P.A.P. Perhaps it may be different with the T.U.C. It is the P.A.P. and the P.A.P. only which can settle its own internal problems and the Government's action particularly in publishing this White Paper was calculated to harass and hinder the P.A.P. in its work. Does the Government believe that by this purge they have saved the T.U.C. for ever more? Or does the Government propose to purge again if the T.U.C. is again threatened? But next time, there may not be a conflict in the P.A.P. to be used as a pretext. The effective way of checking peaceful penetration is by peaceful resistance.

    The Government has chosen to act in the way it did. Now it is up to them to explain their actions and what is more important to show that they have not arrested innocent people. If the Government thinks that because some of these men arrested have opposed us in the past we are not going to fight for their rights under the law, they are mistaken.

    But surely the biggest inaccuracy which is just a parliamentary way of saying falsehood in the White Paper is in paragraph 36:

    "A determined and successful bid for controlling the P.A.P. has been the second feature of recent months.... have gone far to obtain domination of the whole Party organisation."

    The Communists have not made a successful bid for controlling the Party. They have not obtained domination of' the Party. The non-Communist leadership of the Party had not been ousted. The Government's own action in not arresting seven out of the twelve Central Executive Committee members of

Column: 2603

the Party is an admission that at its highest even if the Government can prove that every one of the five arrested are Communists or their agents, the Communists are still not in the majority and not in control of the Party. To say as the White Paper states in paragraph 36 that the Communists had obtained domination of the whole Party is manifestly untrue. It was a fabrication by the Government to justify their action. I challenge the Government to deny that they would have carried out this purge in any case because of the threat to the T.U.C. and that they used the so-called Communist domination of the P.A.P. as a mere pretext.

    The Labour Front Coalition may try to discredit the P.A.P. but they will never succeed in destroying the P.A.P. We are a virile and a genuine political organisation. We shall always remain so. No one, neither the Labour Front Coalition nor the M.C.P., can discredit or destroy us. The Government may close us down but our movement goes on. We stand uncompromisingly for an independent, democratic, non-Communist, socialist Malaya by democratic and constitutional means and we shall not waver from this stand. We believe that by only free competition within the non-Communist democratic system can such a socialist society be achieved in Malaya; that it is not possible in Malaya to achieve Socialism by the Communist one-party dictatorship. In multi-racial Malaya with three major races - Malays, Chinese and Indians - all with differing cultural and linguistic backgrounds, and even more important, with different political traditions and concepts, the dictatorship of any one party may lead to racial conflict and disaster.

    We are not afraid to fight for what we believe in. Our Party policy is fundamentally correct. We have proved it in the past and shall prove it again in the future. The P.A.P. can only be destroyed by the P.A.P. by deviating from our correct stand. Our stand is clear, consistent and unwavering. Our tactics may change according to changes in the political situation.

Column: 2604

It may be adjusted to fit each phase of the anti-colonial struggle. But we are clear, honest and undeviating in our objectives. And we will not be deterred from these objectives either by threats from the colonial power or from the Communists or from anybody else. The Straits Times, voice of colonial vested interest, will not shift us into a hysterical anti-Communist stand. For Malaya to join the mad crusade of Formosa and South Korea in "liberating" Asia from the Communists will only add grave problems for ourselves. Nor, may I add, will we fulfil the hope of Freedom News, voice of the Malayan Communist Party, that - I quote the White Paper which quotes Freedom News - "P.A.P. inclinations can be changed." We are firm in our belief that the democratic road is the only road possible to a Socialist Malaya and we shall fight to prevent the democratic system from being destroyed in Malaya.

    We admit, Mr Speaker, Sir, that it is a difficult role to play. If you do not accept the embrace of colonialists, then the colonialists charge you with being pro-Communists. If you reject the advances of the Communists, they charge you with being pro-colonialists. We have not the slightest intention of being embraced by or being dependent on either of them. We will pursue our democratic, non-Communist Socialist objectives without regard to whether we please the pro-Communists or the anti-Communist group. We shall fight both to the extent to which they stand in the way of our objectives. Our intention is to build up our strength and our following of people who believe in our ideals and who will be prepared to fight for these ideals. But in this fight we shall not make the mistake of allying ourselves with so-called anti-Communist forces which are often cloaks to hide reactionary elements ranging from colonial vested interests to enemies of democracy.

    But now with an independent Federation of Malaya and a new constitution for internal self-government next year for Singapore, a new phase opens in the battle for the future of Malaya. Now

Column: 2605

the time has come to state precisely what kind of system of government our independent Malaya is to have and what we wish to do with our independent Malaya. That was why we took the Tanjong Pagar by-elections as the opportunity to clarify and re-emphasise our long term objectives-an independent, democratic, non-Communist Socialist Malaya. That the P.A.P. defended the constitutional proposals in the Tanjong Pagar by-elections, that we were resolute in honouring our agreement in the All-Party conference

Instead the Labour Front had the impertinence to pinch our Tanjong Pagar by-election platform without acknowledgment or so much as if you please. They say in paragraph 38:

    "The present government stand for the complete internal self-government of the people of Singapore and independence through merger with the Federation.

    Sir, why did not the Labour Front candidate for the Cairnhill by-elections put this over on his platform? Why was it not in his election manifestos which were sent to me at 38 Oxley Road where I live in his constituency? Of course, we are flattered to know that the Labour Front has seen the P.A.P. light. But is it not a stupid thing to try and bankrupt us while at the same time borrowing from our political credit?
